author: oaklandmatt
content:
imho, a lot of the vocals I'm hearing from younger record makers are sounding heavily  processed in the same way. "Lack of dynamics" doesn't really explain it because people think of dynamics as dynamic range compression. It's more that everyone is chopping, clip gaining, and RXing to an evenness that softens and linearizes performances. 

These tools work beautifully when shitty mic technique makes things boomy, or there's a few weird ss's on the pre-hyped TLM mic through the focusrite pre.

But it sounds like most people who learn the tools are overusing them like crazy. 

I'm trying these days to get off the details and try as much macro-mixing as possible. When I let performances breathe in their imperfections, I find that I'm drawn in more as a listener.

"Music is the space between the notes". 
-Claude Debussy

"Music is the space between RX moves." 
-Ruairí (probably)

author: peterlabberton

author: BatMeckley
content:
Working on a mix today, we’ve been grinding on it a lot, a song recorded in lets say a “less than ideal way”. First half of the first verse just wasn’t right on the vocal. Threw everything I had it. Compressor after compressor, soothes, spectres, automations, eq before and after, still not quite right. Took off all the compressors. 1 eq. Readjusted the levels. Perfect. 

Sometimes the best thing you can do is get perspective and be willing to undo everything you’ve done.

author: chrissorem
content: There is a Japanese philosophy that I really like and try to incorporate in my life that contrasts the modern way of wanting to get to the finished product with little effort.   *Kodawari* is a Japanese word describing the commitment to a personal quality standard when undertaking a particular action. For some, this may be their work, hobby, or a leisure occupation such as gardening. Kodawari involves paying *“extraordinary attention to very small details”* and taking pride even in the slightest improvement.

author: chrissorem
content: I often do this regardless if it’s my own production.  I’ll work on a mix and when it  feels like it’s in the 95% zone I’ll make a stems session and pretend I’m a “finisher mixer” haha.  But really,  there is something to having only a handful of tracks to work with and generally this is major automation time for me. I’ll do passes with all fader in automation and see if I can get the damn thing to move more and be bolder,  without the having to think about this previously complicated mix.

author: Matt Huber
content:
Ah yes. The monthly tailspin, I know it well 😂

One thing that I have found to be very helpful to reduce masking / increase clarity  is to simply start by going track to track and listening for / EQing out non musical resonances and non-musical buildups. 

I am definitely NOT suggesting the aggressive hyper notching you see in a lot of YouTube tutorials, but a general track to track cleanup of obvious issues. Don’t over think it, only attack the obvious things 

Hypothetical Examples:
- weird 1.5k resonant ring in the hats and overheads…notch that thing down a bit. You’d be surprised how much space that takes up in a dense mix. 
- high lead guitar part with extraneous rumble at 200hz…not contributing to the musicality of the part…byeeee
- piano building up at 300hz in the choruses when everything is competing for midrange - automate EQ in chorus to create space 


Etc etc etc. 

Small moves like that have made some of the biggest differences for me. Definitely not the fanciest tip, but simple EQ moves have been the biggest contributor to midrange clarity for me.

author: bobby k
content: shifting gears for a sec - something i've been a big fan of this year is duplicating a lead vocal and stripping back any compression / dynamic control to a secondary track with no output, then putting any reverb sends on that track instead of the main ldv. this saves pretty much any instinctual reverb automation "throws" and the such because the vocals natural dynamic is lighting up the reverb the same way it would in real life. it now strikes me how odd and unnatural it would sound to have a vocal hitting the reverb about as hard during soft moments as during dynamic moments. unfortunately there are many cases where this is simply not possible as i'm already starting with a heavily compressed vocal. maybe i'm late to this, but anybody else do this or something similar with success?

author: BatMeckley
content: Oh man I’m having this conversation right now with an artist that I’m working with that’s had a mixer that really likes 44.1 mix the song. The song sounds sonically perfect, balanced, and… flat. My current argument is a good mix needs someone not afraid to get dramatic. Throw a fader. When that best thing happens in verse two, don’t be afraid to push that shit UP. Let the listener feel it, and then it’s cool to bring it back into the mix and their ear can follow it back in. Ride those faders. Keep it moving. Be cognizant of when and WHY  things are brought into the track, yank the fader up at that point. Too many mixers are mixing like they’re afraid to get it wrong, rather than daring to make it special.

author: peterlabberton
content: Here's my clip gain process: is the blob too big? Clip gain it down. No blob? Clip gain it up.

author: cian riordan

Because I did not need compression.
Then they came for the faders, and I did not speak out—
Because I had clip gain.

author: cian riordan
content: Also what @Zack Hames said, downbeat automation is big. If something is loud at the very beginning of a section, then comes back down in volume, the ear will perceive it to be loud for the section. So quickly automating drums + cymbals, big piano chords, guitars, etc -- just for a moment -- will go a long way at making sections exciting. I'm also a fan of slowly lowering the volume of certain instruments right before section changes to give the perception of loudness and excitement on the downbeat.

author: bobby k
content:
Mind if I ramble? I'm working on what is probably the most challenging mix I've done this year. I've been at my first pass for close to 2 weeks, and have probably started it over 4 times. For context, it's a very dense country rock song with like 80-90 tracks, heavy heavy buss processing, many layers hitting exceptional stages of compression and saturation. The most challenging part is that, despite my philosophical differences from the producer's template, the rough mix really works. Anytime I try to strip it back, import my template, do my own thing, make the mix fit into my "mixing philosophy", it just falls apart. I've considered stemming it out with Bounce Factory through his template to then put the tracks into my template, but that would be a zero sum game I can already expect to lose. 

Ultimately I've had to shift my perspective of wondering "why am I here?" I'm learning that my role is not to run this song through some proprietary process I take pride in, but to simply just help them reach the finish line by trying to understand and continue within the process they've already deeply baked this song through. I've found that I can apply my perspective while setting my "process" aside, and explore what small tweaks or decisions I *can* make that get us the last couple % we might be missing. Any previous approach I've tried I already know would result in a 10+ revision nightmare trying to get back to the original magic of the rough.

And on the interpersonal front, I've decided against sharing any of this struggle with the artist. Maybe the mix that gets approved of the 4 that I've done is the one I spent 30 minutes on, but the many hours of me feeling like I'm "failing" on the other 3 passes were needed to understand that this track only needed 30 minutes of my time. Excuses don't get us to the finish line. 

What has been your experience in these situations?

author: bobby k
content: i learned something new about Soothe yesterday that I found valuable - the "soft" vs "hard" mode doesn't affect ratio so much as it affects how the threshold behaves. Soft has what I understand to be a "smart" floating threshold that kind of rides the signal, versus hard is closer to a fixed threshold (and I believe depth then affects the ratio and threshold in it's own way). So, if you were trying to zone in on a frequency that only occasionally rears it's head, hard mode with a lower depth will be generally more accurate and not affect the other parts of the audio nearly as much. I don't like using Soothe on sibilance, but I actually found it quite effective after learning this by setting it to hard mode with a very broad "sharpness".

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I picked up Jon and @oaklandmatt ‘s tip and started doing throws pretty exclusively directly on tracks. 

When the lead vocal is most of the way there (maybe there’ll be subtle adjustments to the LV processing, but it’s more or less up to EU regulations), I do a *commit up to this insert* (which keeps it mono, rather than a right click commit on the track title) on the whole vocal. 

I mute the entire resulting clip, then just unmute the bits I need for a given throw. I’ll duplicate this track (without inserts), maybe end up with 4 of them with different FX chains. It’s no biggie just for a H-Delay and a vintageverb/metaflanger/ whatever.

Like they mentioned on the podcast, this method encourages more experimentation for me, and also circumvents niggly things like trying to get a word to echo on the downbeat if it was sung on an offbeat - you just move the clip forward or backward in time. And if an Ess is too apparent, you can clip gain it down in the source etc.

Plus once you have your verb throw set, when you in turn commit that throw, whatever it is about seeing the audio just suggests further details like having it cut abruptly on a beat, or reverse it, or fade it in, or EQ it etc.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So I’ve been staunchly against clip-gaining for “compression” on vocals until today.

Tracked a vocal yesterday without compressing on the way in for the first time in forever. Clip gaining into ITB compression ended up sounding like good mic technique. Clip gaining *after* compression just sounds like… bad volume rides?

author: Eric Martin
content: this shouldn’t need to be said, but don’t clip gain the life out of an instrument played by humans, it can be tempting to shape things like a programmed track, but there’s life in micro dynamics.

author: Adam Thein
content:
Something that resonated with what @BatMeckley said an hour ago - “don’t be afraid to start from zero again”

Especially while you are learning maybe trying a few approaches is worth the extra time when there is not a deadline you are up against.

I’ve had a few mixes this year where I’m toward the end of the mix and have been living with a vocal chain for a while and just pull everything off it only to realize it just needed a little more top end and a touch of automation here and there when I had 8 plugins on it before.  That’s maybe an exaggeration but the idea is lean into what’s great about digital mixing - save a version, try something new.  If you are versioning there is always a way back to where you were.  Repetition and experimentation will help you find ways to solve problems and speed things up for you down the road.

I woke up and @BatMeckley 's posts about automating EQ popped into my head. Setup two bands and went through the performance in touch mode, rode them like faders. Job done. Discord FTW.

author: aemaury
content: RX Connect in audiosuite is my jam. Send clips to the offline, work the magic by hand and fly it back. soundflow+streamdeck can really cut down on the clicking around for this process. I also find littering the vocal chain with several deessers, each catching like 1-2 db, can sound very natural. It’s a lot to juggle but i do it near the end of the mix once everything is sitting nicely and gain structure is unlikely to change. If that’s not enough, I’ll start manually clip gaining sibilance down 2-5db, or more if the compression is silly.

author: BatMeckley
content: Also, old school I know, but you can chase de essers around for 6 hours or you can just go through with an eq and print the ess sounds in the track. Take down a high shelf, or a wide q dip, find what works on that particular chain, and it should be fairly consistent across most of the esses. Just knock ‘em down right from the jump. Will prob take an hour or so but then your in a much better place for further automated processing down the road.I

author: chrissorem
content: I can answer the stacked eq for myself.  Usually it’s a visual thing (one might be normal eq) next might be only mid eq no sides. One might have automation one might not. Some times the artists wants to hear an eq move. Ok new eq. Then I bypass it and they see I was right all along

author: Rollmottle
content: Duplicate the bus and route everything to both on and off buses simultaneously. Automate the mutes (or crossfade) of the on and off buses as needed.

author: chrissorem
content:
I usually go through the arrangement and balance each note with pencil automation( you’ll start to see a pattern of which notes are
Jumping out) and ill end up copy pasting to make those all consistent and then I’ll hit a little compression after. I love a dbx 160 on upright

author: chrissorem
content: The thing about clip gain that’s often swept to the side is that it’s the first part of the chain.  It will affect the way it hits any processing after. It can be a great tool in particular early in the mix stage before processing stacks up. Sometimes a region is hitting processing too hard and clip gaining is a great way to deal with that but I often see people clip gaining to turn things down, and don’t forget that what the fader is for,  don’t forget about upstream gain staging

author: cian riordan
content: If you really wanna be a G, go through the tom tracks and just automate the threshold on the gate to just open on the tom hits. That way, you have full control over attack/release/ratio/range and not having to worry about when it's going to trigger or not. This was standard mix prep for EV... did this on every drum mic.

author: Felix Byrne
content:
ime clip gain the best way for most of those huge jumps in volume
once u get a workflow down it can be very quick (quicker than fucking around with 5 compressors for 15 mins trying to get something that works, or spending the next week banging your head against a wall trying to make it work)

ctrl shift is the layer shortcut for all clip gain stuff
C copies (you can bump something up and then copy that gain move - ie +4dB) and quickly select and paste it onto other notes that need a similar amount
V pastes
X cuts (and also creates a fade between two points!!) - this does reset the copy clipboard tho so usually i will do one pass correcting gain and then another pass doing the fades
up and down arrows or scroll lets you adjust up and down by a certain amount (which you can set in preferences)
E lets you insert a point at the current scroll time
B resets the gain to 0

author: oaklandmatt
content:
i don't know anyone who makes modern records who doesn't compress AT ALL. jon has sometimes said he doesn't compress but 98% of the stuff he mixes has TONS of compression before it gets to him. 

like @Zakhiggins said, i dance between clip gain and dynamic processing when i'm mixing, using both 100% of the time. i adjust them back and forth, back and forth. sometimes undoing one in favor of the other. 

using both tools in tandem makes for much better clarity without killing dynamics. even SUPER compressed modern pop vocals are better with lots of little clip gaining. 

sometimes i use clip gain to raise the level of a word and even things out, but sometimes i use clip gain to reduce level and undo the sound of super compression so it's adds dynamics.

author: BatMeckley

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I don’t think it’s that heavy. When you come in full Hero Status, Additional Production is a completely non-threatening ask. It honors both your work and theirs. No need to make it any kind of big deal or get preemptively defensive, (hence the thumbs down on Ryan’s comment.)

When you send your next bounce, include excitement for how the project is turning out and do the ask. 

In my mind, additional production credit can be when you’re doing more than replacing kicks & snares and editing/tuning vocals. If you’re adding parts or fundamentally shaping groove elements, etc. 

But I’ve added guitar parts and replayed bass on songs I’ve mixed and not asked for production credit when it really was about making the mix work. 

It’s a per project thing I think. I rambling, but it sounds like you’re taking pride in the work and everyone is on board. Seems like a no brainer.

author: cian riordan

author: montrose recording
content: strategy #1 clip gain every track down 40 db

author: oaklandmatt
content: The honest answer is to get good with several tools (clip gain, clip eq, cut and paste, RX, soothe2, Weiss, a more standard de-esser, and my most underrated: redrawing the waveform). Then decide which one(s) to use based on the timbre, timing, length, and frequencies of the problem.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
If the reverb's there from production and has to stay:

- It doesn't always need to be heard, sometimes can just be felt
- Sometimes it can be drastically EQd
- Sometimes automated so it's clearly audible when there's space for it, and tucked when there isn't
- Sometimes complementary (but different!) mono ambiences panned around maintain more breathing room than a stereo ambience that might blur the center. Tchad Blake is very good at this sort of thing.

If the reverb's coming from me, added in the mix, and it's not working quickly, I'll take a second and consider whether I've been barking up the wrong tree

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
I am pretty much always happy with: 

1. The old generic waves de-esser 
2. A bit of clip gain beforehand
3. Audiosuite EQ or RX as needed
4. A bit of fader riding after

author: Eric Martin
content:
think of it like linking the sound to the original or not, post for linked sounds: raise the vocal channel vocal reverb follows, I use pre fader sends for things like parallel distortion where I want to sculpt a sound independently of the original (I don’t want the distorted character to change if I raise the volume of the track)

Reverbs are almost always post-fader for me

author: Slow Hand
content:
One habit that I've picked up using Ableton that's really handy is doing all of my volume rides and mute automation with a *utility* plugin. This gives me a few advantages:

1. I can place the rides/mutes exactly where I want in the signal path (into a compressor, before a verb, after a verb, etc)

2. I can easily enable/disable the automation if I want to A/B or simplify while solving another problem.

3. My faders are left solely for global level changes and I can easily mute the channel without mute automation turning it back on/off.

author: JustinLeu
content:
A few more thoughts/ideas that I really like to do.

If using verb as an insert on an instrument:
- on insert 1–put Mondomod (or any panning plugin that will change the track from mono to stereo)  then use this as the pan before the reverb. This lets you place the instrument in the stereo field of the reverb. Doing it with mondo mod allows you to keep it static but also automate movement (small or large) within the verb 🙂

Another idea:
Use Waves StudioVerse (or similar plugin that allows this routing)
-parallel split the dry/wet 
-wet gets what ever verb you want
-Leave the wet panned out-wide
-pan the dry in towards the middle 

Doing it with StudioVerse allows you to avoid making aux-sends and keep it all on the track level. (Very useful on bgvs)

Last idea:
Use a pan control plugin (S1, TrackControl, etc) after the verb so you can make it more mono if you want. 

I love verb/dly haha thanks for letting me talk  about it here…my wife is tired of hearing about it 🥲

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Hey mate, so it sounds like you're saying you would like to practice mixing but have sourced poorly recorded and personally uninspiring material that isn't really mix ready and now you're focusing on clip gain as a potential salve. Is that right?

Moving mountains to frame music in the best light, irregardless of the quality of source material, is part of the game, but I wonder if you've chosen a misaligned exercise to hone your chops.

Clip gain is a wonderful and simple tool. If a peak offends the ear, then you can clip gain it down. If a lyric is lost or hard to hear, then you can clip gain it up. There are useful work flow adjustments we could maybe talk about, but it really is that simple. Listen to the music. How does it make you feel. Adjust accordingly.

author: BatMeckley
content: Also, the space between notes is so key. Automation and gating. The quieter the spaces in between, the heavier the guitar hits.

author: Eric Martin

Remember Jon works on tracks that already have baked in compression, so he’s not adding in more he’s just saturating because of density, the smoothed level is already there, and that’s also post clip gain.

author: sethearnest
content:
The Way to Export All Tracks from Logic to Equal the Exact Mix that the Artist/Producer Left Off From™

1. Any busses you want printed need to be showing as "tracks" in the Arrange window. You can do this from your Mix Window by selecting all busses/auxes you want to print, right-click, choose "Create Track", and now those Busses/Auxes will show up in your Arrange Window. Do this for any and all effects, parallel busses, etc etc

2. ignore step 2

3. Turn on your Cycle range you want to export (yellow bar across the top like Marv said) and select all tracks you want to export

4. File --> Export --> All Tracks as Audio Files

5. If next dialog box doesn't have options showing, smash that Options Button and choose various options
  a. Range: Export Cycle Range Only
  b. Uncheck "Bypass Effects Plug-ins" if you want their processing
  b. Include Audio Tail and Include Volume/Pan Automation selected
  c. Normalize Off

6. I suggest making an AES-Standardly-named New Folder and exporting into that 

7. Export that bad boy

This will ensure you can import into your Industry Standard DAW exactly where they left off, minus the mix bus processing. 

If they're sharing effects (e.g. guitar and vocal both going to a verb), and you want them both wet but also separate, then they'll need bounce those separately or dup the verb send/return (in which case their Valhalla Vintage Verb will be 12dB too loud b/c they'll forget to turn off their 2bus processing when they bounce it separately)

author: Jeremy Klein
content: i’ve had really good results using the amplitude macro in melodyne to essentially automatically clip gain up the quietest parts, and reduce (just a lil bit) the loudest parts.  doing this before compression gives me really even sounding vocals i love

author: BatMeckley
content:
Just in case, I’m going to drop this little reminder: are you SURE your vocal needs all that?

Remember in 90% of what are probably your favorite mixes, Rx didn’t even really exist, nor clip gain. I’d take a step back and try to  assess the macro before you jump straight into the micro on habit and lose perspective of what the performance really needs. Someone here had mentioned how flat and lifeless so many mixes have become, and I can’t help but think the thinking behind this conversation the last few days is a big reason why.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Also, we say "there are no rules" a lot. But actually that's not nuanced enough for my taste (and perhaps, this place).

There are many great "rules." Yes, some are dumb and some are wrong, but many of them are worth learning so you know how to break them.

Things like "cut eq before you compress, boost after" is a really great rule. When you learn to do it and to hear it, you learn why it's so important (pulling low end plosives out of a vocal so it doesn't pin the compressor, for example). From there you learn how and when to break it (I like boosting the 200hz-ish body of a live snare drum into a parallel compressor/ saturator to solidify and have control of that frequency range, automate it for fills, etc.).

IMO this is a great "rule," which is great to learn and then break all the time.

author: cian riordan

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Many different solutions (I’ve done all)

1) Let it pop and RX it out after 

2) Leave it on, automate amount and verify that it’s not changing things with a polarity flip (best done standalone)

3) Print whole mix with and whole mix without and edit in the ending 

4) Figure out why it’s popping and fix at source. DC offset?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
- The classic example of compression is to use a fast release with something like a parallel drum buss. As the release lets go and brings up the room gain you get this urgent and explosive energy. When the room is good, and the compression timing is set right it can really make things sound bigger than real life. Remember we're trying to tell a story here, we can't jam the *actual* real power and size of stadium rock drums into that mono speaker at Target but listen to Paradise City and it tells the story pretty well ... our brain does an amazing job of filling in the rest

- The last example is using something like a good tube compressor on vocals. With a nice soft knee and lots of gain reduction we get bring up a bunch of low level and emotional detail, breathy whispery stuff at the end of lines etc that can really help a lyric connect. Often with something like a good tube compressor we get a healthy amount of harmonic distortion too along for the ride which adds weight to the vocal and draws the listeners attention

author: Slow Hand
content:
Like @Rollmottle said it's capable (I use it all of the time), but it lacks a lot of the really refined features of something like Pro Tools. But that's also because it's not trying to be the best mixing platform. It does a *lot* of things that make it preferable from a writing/arranging perspective, and that far outweighs the cons.

I wish it had EUCON support, because it's hard to get hi-res fader rides from controllers without it. Best I can do is do rides with MIDI values (only 128 values). My solution to this has been to map a MIDI fader to a *Utility* gain plugin and limit the range of the fader move to +/- 6dB so that I can get a good resolution with it across the range of volumes that I want to automate. But that's a pain in the ass.

That said, there's one feature of Ableton that I really miss when I use other DAW's and that's the *Audio Effect Rack* device. I use these *all* the time for so many things like parallel processing, or quickly disabling entire FX chains. They are incredibly useful and they remove the need to mult-out three extra channels to do parallel FX (like you would in Pro Tools).

Sure- I think a few things.

author: spectrummasters
content: @NoahNeedleman @bobby k  ….thought I’d share the success story for any possible future references: I went into rx and effectively reshaped the Hz distribution across the esses and “ch’s” with very precise targeted spectral attenuation to get the stuff up around 10 and some hash at 16 k calmed waaaay down , the same around 6-8 k . This seemed to shape the sound back to something more like its original. Then tons of tiny clip gains , touch of  gullfoss (9%tame ) , touch of spectral shaper between (6-8khz) and fader automation on top of all that ….. sounds clean and controlled now though and no ear stabbing moosh. Feel v chuffed . Rx continues to deliver. Happy days

author: jerikcenteno
content:
Heyo! I work in podcasting as a freelancer and at a podcast/media company. 

Echoing what others have said — get Hush. Get the one that goes in PT and not the standalone app. It’s expensive and can take a very long time to render if you don’t have a lot of RAM, but it is the best thing ever. Some RX stuff for de-reverbing is too artifact-y. 

Either than that, I just approach it like a regular mix! Go to the part where it looks the loudest and busies, and just make sure all the VO’s are about the same level — just “ear-balling” and clip gaining accordingly. The only diff is I use vocal ride from Waves. 

Also, the company I freelance at asks for final files to be -16 LUFS. Not sure if that’s standard everywhere, but just get a limiter where you can read the final LUFS after committing. 

Another tip is I make sure my clip gaining is set to 3.0dB in preferences. If somebody laughs over somebody, I’ll clip gain it down anywhere from 3-6dB.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'd have a talk with the artist - if you haven't already - and get a feel for whether they want to keep it naturalistic (don't touch my performance!) or if they want to juice the sounds and have fun with the sonics - reverb moves, compression effects, weird balance proportions, fader rides, etc.

Without hearing the record, the risk with a lot of noise music is that it gets same-y. So dynamics and sonic interest are your friend. If you can find ways to create contrast and change over 30 second intervals that will go a long way towards engaging the listener. Then again, let's assume that the artist knows what they're doing and has it the way that they want.

If possible, I think it would be fun to invite them in to the mix session and collaborate on the mix with them sitting next to you. Go wild and see what inspires them! Make it into a performance and vibe off of the noise. That might be unorthodox when it comes to mixing records these days, but there's nothing orthodox about this stuff, so have fun!

author: bryan cook
content:
My go to is a 16th note. It may sound like too much when the verb return is loud but when you sink the verb down it usually is really effective for me.

I like to use a mono aux with a delay plug-in for predelays, with a bus as the input and a bus to the verb as the output. No predelay on the verb itself, you make it before hand on this aux. Reason for this being you have a lot of control on your send signal that only the verb hears. A midrangey verb and a full range dry vocal make for depth and texture that can peacefully co exist. You can de ess the send harder than the real LV. With this pre delay aux you can make the send signal darker or brighter. If the song calls for it, make a second aux and have multiple predelays feeding the same verb. For example, a 16th with no feedback that is 80% wet, and a second input bus to same output bus that is dark 1/4 note 100% wet and with feedback where you can automate the send to that long feedback predelay and leave the short no feedback 1/16 static. You can get a lot of mileage out of the same verb with these multiple pre delays and provide some cohesive varied space.

author: kidcutler

author: Deleted User
content: The best tip I can give is moving back at least a foot(!) from the mic on the belted notes. Compression can get weird if the singer has vibrato in their voice(ESPECIALLY parallel compression), of not it’s less of an issue, but can still make certain voices sound like a duck if not done well. I also personally would only do broad-stroke clip gain/clean up and then use automation instead, I’ve had much more success making the dynamics sound natural that way.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Pro tennis players talk about how their perception of the ball is often that of a large, slow moving, target. Their perception and reflexes are so heightened that they have plenty of time to plan and react to an object that is - for everyone else - 3.5" in diameter and rocketing across a large space.

That's how my own productions feel to me at times. They may be speeding along at 160+ bpm and yet feel painfully simple, and predictable. But to everyone else, they're dense rollercoaster rides.

author: Adam Thein
content:
I use it in the last 10% of the mix usually - when I'm at the OK my body is moving, the balances are close, I've got some automation to do but let's see where I'm at on Tonal Balance.  If my top end is generally trending too hot it probably means I've been working for too long and it's time for a break.  

I don't really use it while mixing, but more of a problem solver.  One thing I'll do is if I do see a clump of something somewhere I'll start muting tracks that are in that range to see if a single source is causing the lump or it it's a broader number of sources.  In that way it can be helpful to identify a certain instrument that isn't balanced well.

author: JustinLeu
content: A few things I've found helpful is setting up my mix sessions with many points of control--- VCAs for all groups and then more specific (*All Music* *All Drums* *Kick/Snare* *All Vox* etc...) then a master fader controlling how hard I hit the 2bus. Starting with the biggest section of the song helps as well. I can then automate the other sections up or down *including the master fader feeding the 2bus*  As far as clipping/limiting on sources/busses I find it good to shape the sounds how I want (more heavy lifting) then the busses/2bus end up just glueing it together with a lighter touch. I think the 2bus doing too much of the lifting is where it can start to fall apart.

author: Maxim
content:
It depends on the song but a lot of times you don’t actually want to “hear” the reverb. It should be woven into the performance in a smart way and that’s where choosing the right verb and EQ is essential. 

So I’m not sure if there’s really any “secret” other than developing your ears to hear what’s right and knowing how to get there. 

If a client is asking for “more reverb” I wouldn’t take that literally. Maybe they want to hear more reverb between phrases (automate or use ducking), maybe they want a verb that has more high-end information (plates tend to sound a bit dull unless EQed), maybe use multiple reverbs at different lengths with various characters to compliment each other, etc. etc.

There’s really too many options to give a general response.

But as far as getting the vocal upfront use pre-delay and slap delays to get that width. Dial in the MS amount by ear.

author: Will Melones
content:
I have two thoughts on this. One is to use balance (often fader automation) to bring attention to a particular track moment by moment. Maybe multiple midrange elements will be competing, but the ear can only focus on one at a time (in addition to the drums, bass, and maybe vocal) so YOU choose and shift the focus!

My second approach is to take two or more of the competing tracks, say kick and bass, and play them together. No point in soloing one. EQ one while listening through it to the other. You may notice that you can subtract quite a bit from the bass without losing its character, but the kick’s punch is improved by the space you’re carving out. I do this a lot with vocals, too—focusing on the vocal inside a dense mix while subtracting from all the other stuff that’s stepping on it. When the lead just finds its home in its own uncongested space, you know you’ve got all the surrounding noise right.

author: peterlabberton

I felt like I was getting a little too pristine and, as @BatMeckley said, *flat* with my mixes, and putting the whole song on a few faders, closing all the PT windows, and listening and reacting has been a great trick to play on my brain to just listen to the song and pick out special moments. Often I’ll realize that certain elements can ride down before chorus downbeats/ride up on those downbeats in the process of doing this, and then it’s super easy to execute (and more fun than drawing in a line of automation).

author: Adam Thein
content: I like to reach for brighter verbs in this kind of scenario - something with some texture like a spring or a plate or a digital verb with some texture.  Start there, mess with the width of it first.  Generally think if it more as a synth pad layer.  Emphasizing 2-5k if it really needs to cut with spectre or Saturn or a brighter saturation.  Using a delay in combination so that the decay envelope has some movement so my ear latches onto it more.  Panning, modulation, tremolo, etc, subtle ways to grab attention even at low level.  And good old volume automation.  Printing the verb can help give you some visual feedback for how it’s decaying.

author: JakeTB
content:
Here’s the long-winded human version. We’re still on this learning journey so happy for any pushback or insight

For the most part, our group felt the tradeoffs of very subtle multiband often outweigh the benefits, since just putting those crossovers in the signal makes a bigger difference than, say, a dB of control.

We felt more liberal use of multiband can add an aggression and excitement that is very familiar and unique, and prefer treating it as a sweetener or energizer over the whole mix more than trying to control problem areas that could be addressed on tracks.

In the signal chain, its position can drastically effect how other tools behave. Up front, it can help a bus compressor or saturation device behave more predictably, but may mush things too much. Near the end, it allows those devices to play a more colorful role but may cause weird behavior when using fast, “transparent” limiters afterward. I like it first right now, most of our group like it near the end.

The hallmark signs of overuse for us were mixes that sound overly strident or when a vocal becomes inconsistent tonally from section to section as density changes.

Tools-wise, the group unanimously preferred minimum phase tools over linear phase or dynamic phase. OTT is a starting point, ear training to recognize that color. Once you hear it at 15-20%, you won’t be able to unhear it on many pop records. After ingraining that color, ML4000 and C4 both have their own flavors that can do a thing while offering tweakability when needed.

After trying different EQ + compression techniques, automation just sounded a bit more pleasing to my ears. And made it easier to stick with the up and down dynamics of the song. One thing I’ll say, just as a rule of thumb, I really think keeping your faders at 0 or LOWER is ideal. EQ + Limiter + volume automation most of the time. Sometimes saturation or imaging. Occasionally compression but less and less often these days.

author: Eric Martin
content:
I never do a new session, but I do commit sounds down so that I aim not working around too much automation, and if the automation gets in the way, I usually just make VCA’s to control it.

To me it’s all about perspective, I mostly master other people’s music but also to tracking to final mix productions and the perspective mastering has given me on what a production should sound and feel like has definitely upped my game a lot.

author: Nick Stetina
content:
Feel ya on this. It’s especially apparent when it’s drawn in, all the same MIDI velocity fed into a VI. It takes some real work with volume and EQ automation to give it some movement and life, rather than steam rolling through the production.

Re: EQ, I had some luck doing that recently with ProQ3, finding what worked  as a “darker” organ sound and then enabling automation for ProQ’s mix knob and just working that throughout the track. Makes it easier to have one lane of automation to deal with and you change your mind about the EQ itself, you can make adjustments freely and not worry about changing any of the automation.

author: Josh Bowman
content:
The buss it around the mixbuss is a good idea as long as delay compensation is working right!

One kinda fun thing i've done before with producers roughs which you could totally do on your own mix is, print a mix with the crazy multi band 2 buss, then take it off and try and match that mix by ear with a regular eq and a fader moves. Im always surprised how much cleaner i can get it by rebuilding this way, even if it ends up getting slammed back into the limiter, it ends up usually workout out a little cleaner.

author: cian riordan
content: Hi Jimmy, welcome. Both faders and automation lanes are both tools to achieve the same goals — volume automation. Some prefer the old school feel of faders and many have never really learned to use them and do just fine without them. I have a set it front of me but probably only use them for about 5-10 perfect of the process, if any. Most of it is done with automation lanes as it’s more precise to get the level exactly where you want it and not have to go back and rewind and go over automation passes.

author: spookydrums
content:
If you’re in the soundflow world there’s a script I found in the forums there written by Chris Shaw where I highlight a section and hit my keyboard shortcut (shift+cmd+t for me) and it will separate the region, create crossfades and highlight it, and then I just clip gain up and down with shift+ctrl and the up and down arrows. Such a quick workflow. I also love gainstaging into compression a lot of the time rather than doing it post compression. 

And then there is this other soundflow version of back and play that I hit (ctrl+space bar) where it backs up two seconds and play from there. Amazing for automating vocals.

author: spectrummasters
content:
I fully agree with Josh about perhaps it’s not meant to sound how you had hoped . 

Hang tough man ! You’ll get there . 
I’m sure others will chime in with greater tips but fwiw 

I had a moment like this with a band project a while back . I thought what I’d been given wasn’t good enough to get what I wanted . The turning point for me was realising I had started mixing the songs before I knew the parts , the nuance and strengths and weakness of the performances of those parts and the arrangements of them intimately . I didn’t know all the vocalists lyrics or know the parts of their vocal range that distorted and those that sat perfectly . I realised I was effectively driving a car with my eyes shut . 
My best offer would be : make sure you know everything inside out , and then mix again from scratch …and with old school good balances and fader rides I bet you can bring it to life . 

In knowing every aspect of the performances I was able to anticipate the parts and really bring the interplay of the band to life in the mix properly . Kinda felt that was the key that unlocked the potential that I’d not found before 

Good luck 👍

author: GaspardMurph
content:
Here’s what I do regarding loudness : I try to make the client stems hit my stereo bus around where the red line is by the top of the Mute button (very unprofessional that I don’t know)  - so I usually trim my groups (I have a VCA in my template that controls my different instrument buses’ volume). Usually when getting hot stems it’s around -3 / -4db trim. Rarely I get stems too quiet and in these cases I usually clip gain all stems down. 

Then I usually have ozone vintage limiter on at -2.5db which will add a bit of loudness with the auto gain and then set the maximizer to +2dbs.

By the time I’m done doing my thing with bus processing, eqing etc… I’m usually in a good spot lufs wise and then it’s a matter of turning up or down either the makeup gain on my compressor or the output of the maximized

author: BatMeckley
content:
I think there’s levels to this.

1) I think it’s an error to equate Serban’s value to simply fader moves. His name carries weight in the attention a song gets up and down the line. 

2) if your mix is awesome (which I’m sure it is, you’re great) why are you sending it to another mixer then? If you’re the shit, just be the shit. Actually send it to Ruairi and handle all the mix notes/revisions/stems yourself (or designate to an assistant)

3) I think co mix is fine, but it should be negotiated BEFORE it gets sent to mix. If a producer’s rough is so unfuckwithable, it shouldn’t need a mixer. If everyone thinks it does and want to pay another guy, then maybe the producers mix isn’t as 🔥 as initially believed. 

4) this all started because I said, don’t steal my mix lol. Again, there’s levels, and to say some chucklefuck in a chatsworth apartment’s name carries the same weight and value as the biggest mixer of all time doesn’t feel genuine. I’m getting more value and confidence if Serban goes “I can’t beat it” than if he does. As a producer I’m certainly not handing over my mix to ol CF to boost his brand. But Serban co signing my mix boosts mine.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: Rule of thumb here: Any linear processing (EQ, volume, fader moves, reverbs, delays) is identical whether track vs. bus, and regardless of the order they're in.

If it’s over baked then I would ask for that specific instrument to be sent dry.

author: rse
content:
This is really valuable! Thanks a lot. To go into some of your questions; I'm using Adam a7's (not the newer a7x's, although I tested them and they're wasn't as much of a difference as I had expected in my room). My room has been treated with diy panels, 14cm thick Rockwool and it sounds decent for a home recording studio. the dimensions aren't great and low lend monitoring isn't top of the charts but it's workable. Any peaks and valleys i did have have been sorted out further as much as possible with sonarworks which has really outdone my expectations. I also use Beyerdynamics dt770 pro's. 
Usually a lot of time does actually go into clip gaining, cleaning up and taking harshness out of vocals. I often take as much time just manually leveling a vocal, taking out esses etc as I do mixing. Fresh air and dopamine have indeed been big helpers and have been big steps towards that sizzle. Also the waves exciter in parallel has been working okay.
I never seem to be able to get a multiband compressor to work well. Either I'm overdoing some of the setting or something because often i feel like it attenuates too much and other times to little in the places I want it to. I've noticed that a little boost in the low mids on pro-q3 that then also attenuates dynamically can work. 
Could you go into a bit more detail on what you mean with phase bringing a vocal more forward?
I've also noticed that a lot of the sound I'm looking for comes from a certain sort of rolling kind of sound that might be coming from the rappers throat? I'm not sure at all about this but it seems like it's almost vocal fry but in a very natural way that is inherent to the singers/rappers voice. Idk if this is a rapping technique thing or if this is more accentuated in the mixing process, but it sounds really nice.
Definitely a big thankyou for all the tips!

author: Brodie Stewart
content:
I’ve been dealing with this today, but the vocalist has extremely bright/sibilant/harsh strident capsule resonances popping up in different places like 5k, 7k, 10k etc. Sometimes the tightest q cuts worked at the pin-like resonances piercing through, other times a literal notch provided the smoothest results. I was trying Soothe for anything above 5kHz and sometimes it worked and sometimes it didn’t.

Different sections and phrases had different capsule resonances, like the tube in the mic was fluctuating based on temperature/humidity causing all sorts of nasties. I ended up using Audiosuite on the odd phrase here or there and manually cutting the resonances with a tight Q or notch (in addition to what was on the channel).

author: BatMeckley
content:
So I had to mix this live thing for an artist, and her mic technique left much to be desired with resonances… multi band won’t cut it… so…

Open up fab filter, engage the visual RTA, grab a fairly sharp bell, and set the gain and the frequency to write on your automation. Now, literally go through the track, and chase the specific resonances like you were playing and old 80’s arcade game. You should be able to see them pop up in the rta, then just counteract them with the least amount of gain reduction that you can get away with. Usually takes me 3 passes total to really dial it in. 10-15 minutes later, alll good!

author: spectrummasters
content: I can relate to this . I think first impression notes are a great tool and I’m challenging myself to “do less “ not more to roughs:demos . Often times when I’m tracking vocals it is to a two track (rnb/hip-hop) and I’ve learnt that just about any “vocal sound “ I want to go for I better get it whilst we are tracking because the artists always want a rough vocal mix to go away with at end of session . Invariably , whatever that rough sounds like I can’t stray away from (for good or bad ) once they’ve heard it . And then when it comes to a final mix , it gets even more complicated getting the actual stems for the two track and mixing it all down with the vocal tracks as it often (imo) sounds better but doesn’t feel the same as that on the day rough vocal mix to the two track . I realised there’s no way I can get an artist to unhear that first  rough mix and I’m wasting hours mixing it all over again with the stems , like I’m re inventing a wheel no one wants . I’ve noticed @Bainz_  telling @oaklandmatt he had the same issues with thugs punk album and also have heard Jason Goldberg and Stuart white embracing the idea that you’re possibly mixing the final mix/pre master as you track . It’s a very raw and quick approach and it does keep you miles away from overmixing something . I embraced it as a workflow only recently and it’s less stressful than working your ass off on a “perfect” mix only to get back they prefer the vibe of the first day mix .   top tips not to overmix I am meditating on currently are : don’t lose your dynamics , watch your phase relationships don’t change , leave some mistakes in , automate more than compress and be quick

author: Joe Thomas
content: Can anyone give me some tips on mixing electric bass? The performance itself is pretty smooth, but I've used clip gain to level spots out a bit, eq, compressor with medium fast attack fast release, limiter with the same, saturation, distortion, and there are still notes getting lost throughout the take.

author: Deleted User
content:
I’m ruling out the performance since you said it is smooth- but great bass guitar performance often don’t need much clip gain because good players know how to adjust their touch to the acoustic properties of the instrument.

Sometimes it’s arrangement, when instruments are playing notes that aren’t really meaningful to the arrangement then it won’t cut through the mix. Or if the other instruments are doing things that aren’t meaningful to the arrangement, it can get contribute to bass notes getting lost as well. 
Try muting other stuff one at a time until you can hear the bass well, and evaluate why the bass isn’t cutting through. 

Sometimes, you just gotta zoom out and mute the bass and mix the song without the bass and put it in. Before you do this, save as and solo vocals (if there is any) bass and drums (sometimes one other most important/prominent element in the arrangement on top of that) and make that work first. You can get it to a point of making the mix work this way if there is one element that just doesn’t sit well in the mix.

author: Adam Thein
content: I’ve never had much luck with the auto-ducking features personally - usually a little volume automation on the delay itself gets me what I’m after faster.  Or using a compressor with a hold stage like Fabfilter C2 sidechained to the original with a slower release can sometimes be transparent.  Or honestly using the delay as an insert into compression will release really naturally.

author: Deleted User
content:
I find that delays can take some aggresive EQs depending on the style. Give a wild boost on area where I want the delay to cut through and turn the overall delay down - and then compress it a little bit to duck it. 

At least for reverb- I find it’s not always necessarily to have a dry signal keying the compressor to duck the reverb.  Sometimes just a compressor directly on the channel will do something similar and less dramatic than ducking if that’s what is needed for the song, 

Also I find faders very helpful in automating effects. Because I don’t always want them to duck in the same shape or ducking is something I’d do to change the nature of the tail and will still need some additional shaping to give specialness to different moments.

For vocals I like copying the audio track and make separate fx tracks because I only want it on certain words. Even for overall effect, I use a separate track so I can take out certain words from reverb or clip gain them. Or even fade in words when I don’t want the early part of reverb poking out too much in certain parts.

author: mixedbywong_my
content:
“Using the Gain Scale slider, just below the gain level/pan knobs, you can scale the effect of the gain settings of all curves by dragging horizontally. This can be very useful when you want to automate the overall effect of the EQ.

Note: This only affects the EQ shapes that actually offer a gain setting: Bell and Shelving filters. It will not affect the other filter types.”

author: Ross Fortune
content:
[Apologies for long message, I’m thinking out loud but also detail is probably useful] Gearing up to mix a live album with a heap of songs (tbc but potentially 23 in one show).

The last time I did something like this, it was low channel count -   a couple of acoustics, one or two vocals, maybe a keyboard per song. I mixed the whole thing in one Pro Tools session, with a separate set of channels for each song which I’d then make inactive and move onto the next song. When printing the continuous mix at the end, I’d make active two songs at a time for any overlap, and constructed the long printed mix like that.

In this case though, there are multimiced drums, bass, electric guitars, keyboards, vocals. The recordings are good (from the stereo board mixes I’ve heard) and the scale is such that I want to have the fidelity I’d approach a studio record with, and the room to shape an identity for each song (while still sounding like they all happened on the same stage on the same night) so I’m thinking to use my usual elaborate drum mix routing with parallels etc, all the bells and whistles.

This complexity would put me off mixing 23 songs in one session, but I’m thinking of the inevitable crunch at the end of the project and the potential frustration of jumping between sessions.

Am I thinking too deeply about this? Should I just get a drum sound and leave it there for 23 tracks, with a few rides here and there?

Not much experience with this stuff so any thoughts would be very welcome please!

author: Will Melones
content:
I have nowhere near the experience you do, but I’d approach this in one session. So when you get to song 16 and discover that perfect kick sound, or get a note from the artist that the bass could come up 2dB for the whole show, you’re not opening 23 sessions to revise.

But my approach would also be one set of tracks from beginning to end, just like you’re mixing it live, and prepare to automate. What made you choose a separate set of channels for each song?

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So think of mid vs side in terms of panning left right & center, and think of EQ as volume. 

If you’ve got a lot of low end information on the sides, and say it’s fighting with a mono bass track that’s supposed to be holding down the majority of the low end, you can eq the lows out of those panned tracks, or you can blanket turn all the lows down on the sides with a m/s eq on a buss, so that the L and R info is quieter. It’s basically a group volume ride for frequencies instead of tracks. You can also do this on individual stereo tracks if just panning isn’t granular enough. 

The why & when is mostly about taste. I tend to mix into a proQ3 setting that has the sides hi passed around 100 for the same reason I have a pultec boosting highs & lows on the master- it just ends up doing a lot of work for me.

It can become problematic if I’ve got big toms in a song and, after I’ve got a mix starting to cook I’ll toggle it on & off to see if I’m doing more harm than good. For the kind of music I mostly do, it works more often than not, but the one song I sent to Cian for mixing he basically blasted me for doing that. (In his own kind and gentle way.)

But m/s eq isn’t just for the master buss. You can think about it for any stereo track. Sometimes, I have an acoustic that’s carrying the whole song, but the fundamentals are fighting with the vocal, so I’ll turn the mid down at that frequency (or side chain that to the vocal if it feels anemic when the vocal is out.) that leaves the sides as big as you like cause it’s not fighting with my mono vocal.

Question for the braintrust: I need to adjust several hundred finished song files to meet a -0.3dB max peak spec. They're currently anywhere from -1.0 to -0.0 as they sit (already finished/mixed/mastered).

First thought is to bring them into Pro Tools, lower each by -0.5dB w/global clip gain move, SHIFT-OPT-3 those to make new audio files, then export those now-quieter files (SHIFT-OPT-K). 

Is there a more efficient way to batch process them? Or anything I'm not thinking through? True Peak isn't specified. Too big of a number of songs to reopen all the original sessions and re-export.

author: Jeff Dunne

I literally have note frequencies written on a midi controller in sharpie for reference. Denise bass xxl seems to have a midi in which could be a good compromise.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Can I ask what is the bigger goal of these automated note changes on your EQ?

author: Jeff Dunne
content: To clarify, I’m automating the frequency control in Rbass, not on an eq. It does a cool “something” on bass guitar in a metal/rock context for me that in particular helps on smaller speakers, but also helps to fill out space where some notes are naturally stronger than others. It helps me avoid a lot of tedious automation and multiband babysitting in addition to providing somewhat of a rock solid “concrete slab” consistent low end. I always loved what Rbass did but the effect vanishes a little when the progression of the song moves to a different note - automating the frequency in question (super low, where A = 55hz) solves that problem for me but is a chore to do.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
A year or so ago I went deep on this. 

First thing is, and you’ll hear this a lot around here, monitoring. Making sure your monitoring is good will allow you to hear where the esses are problematic and when you’ve gone too far, etc. 

Secondly, all my de-essing woes pretty much disappeared when I started using RX. 90% of the time I run DeEss module and slap Waves DeEss (around 7khz) on the end of the chain and it’s golden. May still have to clip fx / clip gain one here or there but it’s largely just handled.

author: Josh Bowman
content:
Oooff feel your pain that’s rough. This happens to me from time to time, not always that extreme tho.

Generally my first move is to listen while bypassing each thing and trying to identify what it’s making better and what gets worse, then if I decide to try and keep some of them I’ll attempt to move some of those plugs off the main mix buss and back onto a subgroup or instrumental buss. But no matter what it ends up with me looping sections and rebuilding the mix to match the rough vibe before I get into the actual creative fun part of the mix.

I have one producer i work with often who mixes into a comp on his all vocal buss and it’s slow and hitting like 3-6 db compression. It totally bones me while mixing so I usually end up rebalancing all the vocals section by section to match his mix before I “start mixing”. 

Sometimes I’ll just work into their buss shit and bypass the stuff/bands of each of plug that are only hurting and not helping. 

Real can of worms tbh. 

Last week I ran into the vocal buss issue- luckily it was a comp w side chain input so I did try out the sidechain, I pre fader sent all the tracks feeding it while copying automation to that send, then used a master fader to match the buss sc level to the original comps gain reduction  and it worked well in that situation and untied my hands while saving me from a whole vocal rebalance session. First time that approach ever actually worked though for me tbh. If its a comp that drums are driving into i find the sc input doesnt end up feeling the same usually.

author: onanisland
content:
Generalizing here without context but usually a "ballad piano" to me is in the softer spectrum, so sometimes desicion making is > check stereo image to lock in perspective > use an eq or something that doesnt overally emphasise the 3-4khz range > sometimes a Vari-Mu can ride the piano really well and give the warmth - and don't overdo it, Cinematic Rooms or VSS4 reverb for a realistic-ish space placement.

For cutting more though the mix I second spectre for brightness, but I also like the harrison EQ, it has really musical curves to get it to cut through without sounding "too much"

author: Iwan Morgan
content: Balance, pan and faders are your best friends here as Josh and Spectrum advised - this may mean getting a really good static balance or it may mean using automation to get the overall shape/macro dynamics of the mix in check.  Having been down this road many times I would forget about references at first and just get a musical balance based on the music which is actually in the DAW. Then make sure you do a 'Save as' and then start maybe adding basic EQ and compression to some elements, and just keep chipping away.  They can be tough but very rewarding projects where the upside is that you get to really maximise learning/skills!

content: no, not doing anything wild automation wise. seems to just be a weird glitch. i use the VCC on each of my busses so without it the whole session vibe is off and then some random distressor parallel stuff throughout... so rebuilding isnt the worst case... just an extra 30mins i didnt wanna spend on these tweaks to just get the session to sound like what was originally printed. definitly going to move away from VMR though as this has been happening randomly when i get sessions and things prepped from the assist.

author: onanisland
content: You've already got great advice above! Listening at low levles helps a lot with balancing throughout, solo safe against other instruments / groups to find what to cut to make space for vocals  (with time you'll find this to be intuitive), I'll add something to the convo, when I had new assistants in to help them place the vocal I'd tell them to solo drums + bass + vocals and adjust level of the vocals - and that'd be a great a starting point, additonally I'd have them press the mono button with everything playing on the controller and listen at conversational level to ride it, and sometimes I'd suggest to create a "harmonics" group with all the gtrs, piano, banjos whatever and just see what the mids of those would sound like vs vocal, if they put spreader/doubler, we'd check sides only too

author: hyanrarvey
content: Print and fade out or automate

author: Josh Bowman
content: Usually a faderport ride then tweak individual elements at the track level with VCAs that need to pop out more or less near the end of the fade. Usually ill delete a bunch of the automation points after to make it smoother but use the fader to get the general arc feeling good.  A few times last year i actually just used the ssl comp fade out button in the waves SSL comp but it becomes annoying if there are fade related revisions later. Does the thing tho!

author: thegreatcarsoni
content: I made a mistake this last month using the SSL auto fade that was pre a lot of other processing on the mix bus. At the end of the mix the artist decided they wanted the ME to do the fade. Well I had done a bunch of other rides with individual elements based on the fade from the SSL. So I had to uncook all that and it was super annoying. Lesson learned there.

author: Josh Bowman
content: Does anyone know what the ssl button curve is? Id imagine by now someone has just ported it over to PT automation.. Is it just the S fade?

author: matthewrederburg
content: Agree on both points here. Often my fades resemble an s-curve, and there’s often an element of the fading audio that will get its own automation. Sometimes things just pop out or don’t pop out enough during a fade. Sometimes a good sounding full band fade will end at a weird part in a drum pattern and I’ll drop out an offending drum hit to placate my ear.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Anyone here have any principles / tips for automating vocals? (I think of principles as the closest thing to a rule that is a core concept that isn’t as rigid as a rule but is something to keep in mind)

For anything to do with vocal automation: efficiency, quality, genre specific, etc.

For example, I find myself using a mouse to automate vocals. It takes hours as I go syllable by syllable then relisten to line by line then in context of the section then in the song etc. I burn myself out doing it, and it’s my least favorite part of all music creation. I want to see if there’s a way I can use a fader, or perhaps have a mindset where I’m not so intense about it. I’m sure I’m going overboard, but lack confidence in knowing if it works aside from trying, using my ear, tweaking, listening, etc etc over and over.

Anything to do with a standard workflow, mindset, techniques, etc. could help me improve this part of the work. Or perhaps, what I’m doing is the deep work and there is no shortcut?

I’m very invested in anything anyone could contribute on this topic. It feels like my mixing nemesis.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content: I don’t have a hard system but will do what I feel is needed for that take. Sometimes I’ll then compress some more and bounce before automating, sometimes automate after, sometimes other things.

author: cian riordan
content: Not to mention the myriad other variables — ie, maybe there’s other instruments masking the vocals and that’s why you need so much automation.

author: cian riordan
content: Once you start carving out and sorting out the arrangement, ideally it’s just small rides on the vocals to get things to sound clear

author: onanisland
content:
Here's how my assistants do vocal rides: put volume at talking levels, hit mono button on monitor controller, play song and ride the vocals, if its still too much, solo Drums + Bass + Vocals. 

Ofc this solo process after u have sculpted the harmonics instrs

author: Juliette
content:
Question: When you’re tracking that close to the 0.0db mark, does turning the clip gain down effect the punchiness/fullness of the sound?

This is something I’ve struggled with, especially with mixing metal and harder rock within amp sims. I’m too scared to track over -15 to -9dB now because it’s left me a lot of room to raise the volume if need be, lol

author: Eric Martin
content: I’m not on your level, but the rate is the rate for all my independent clients, unless they negotiate, which I take in stride to do the projects because I need every one of them.

author: JustinLeu
content:
Also have done quite a few live recordings (mostly ccm) depending on how it is edited/tracked, the drum bleed in to the vocals will be something to figure out. 
A few things I have had a lot of success with:

-Waves “Clarity” run at a light setting can be surprisingly helpful (you can automate the depth too)
-izotope music rebalance can help with this too, but use it super sparingly and on a new playlist. 
-RX can clean up a multitude of sins…both editing issues and annoying random audio issues.

As far as rate, it really just depends. The ccm stuff I have done is always just as much if not more work than studio stuff I get. Charge accordingly, I would do full rate if you can.

author: revolution
content:
anyone want to have a chat about **clip gaining vocals** in a beginner friendly way?

I recently cold DMd some random discord artists who sent me a few things to be able to practice mixing. Im totally new to doing any kind of intentional or thorough mixing. I got back beginner stuff (hip hop) and so far only two track projects,;so I'm primarily focused on vocal clean up, mix, and production. 

I have a vocal that is loud and energetic but I believe was recorded too close to the mic (or too loudly). I cleaned up the take in RX as best I could and did some slight de-clipping on the really bad peaks. I've imported it back to PT, and took some of the basic tips from the podcast notes into consideration. I want to clip gain the vocal and try to even it out without being transformative or destructive of the performance, but still taking enough liberties to improve it and learn something.

author: revolution
content:
I already had the instinct myself to use clip gain a good bit when I record my friend or demos for my friend, so I was excited to get the validation about how useful/important this can be (especially for weaker performers), but thinking of how to holistically do it with the intention of prepping the vocal is causing a bit of overthink perhaps. There's also the question of more granular clip gain for de-essing or plosives, etc., that makes me wonder what would be overdoing it or what is even needed and how to judge that.

Usually any "mixing" or editing I do is related to ideas I create or am part of capturing and have vision/inspiration and get some level of enjoyment out of it. This inspiration usually provides intention or some direction even in my ignorance. In this case I'm completely detached and uninspired essentially, while this makes me more objective, I have a hard time hearing where I want to take the vocal. 

I would appreciate some perspective and insight into the granular thought process one might take with the source material I have, having more experience and know-how. I will push through on my own and seek out feedback that way as well, but some live soundboarding would be nice. I appreciate you regardless if you read this and if you have any input at all. ty!!

If you are interested in listening or discussing it, ping or DM me. We could chat about it in vc and I could stream. Thanks again, I hope good discussion can come of this in a way that is granular or useful for curious beginners.

author: revolution
content:
Honestly I was just having a hard time listening and understanding the impact of clip gain at a more granular level, and generally wannting someone to soundboard with or  have a session with through a mix. I think a better approach will be for me to finish my attempts entirely adn ask for feedback.

But I was curious on what approach people took to treating the vocal pre vocal chain in order to deal with problems like peaks, sibilance etc. I was having a hard time hearing subtle changes, and the overall vocal is loud and present, so simple things like matching the overall volume arent really a challenge. I'm used to those kinds of gain adjustments from tracking rappers.

author: cian riordan
content: I mix records every day of my waking life. I use clip gain to solve problems. I will typically get a chain going for the main vibe of the song, then clip gain into it to adjust when necessary.

author: tinkerjef
content: clip gains an extension of gain staging, just at a finer level

author: Josh Bowman
content: There is no set process. But what @cian riordan just said is exactly what happens over here most of the time. Spend some time messing around with clip gaining, see how it impacts the rest of your chain, and then you will learn slowly when its a tool you need to bust out, and when you dont. Dont just clip gain because clip gain. Its all context and recording dependant as is everything in mixing. Clip gain is just volume, but pre-inserts. Nothing special going on.

author: cian riordan
content: Option A) clip gain down the chorus vox

author: Dalliance
content:
I've had clients where I produced the shit out of backvocals. I'm talking delay throws with paralell fx chains triggered by Envelope followers with automation over automation that took a good amount of time to dial in. I completely killed it because the track was empty without it, but the feedback went something like "chill out with the creativity." Which just made me realize that sometimes it does not pay off to go the extra mile with people who do not appreacite your input. 

The "sees the differential" resonates with me, but not only with the market, but also the client. I'm telling you some of these people will tell you what's wrong with the "filter" but won't notice the kick is panned left, so I hardly doubt the artists, mush less listeners, notice the lack of clicks  pops, gain automation, just right amount of sibilace, and just enough tuned vocals. What they do notice is that "it slaps". 

We've just had an indie artist break through the market here. From hundreds of monthly listeners to hundreds of thousands. Dude must've recorded the music on his phone and mixed it himself. I'm purposefully omiting the word "master." And well, the listeners do not care and still consume the melody and the lyrics, so I don't know what would have to happen for people to appreciate sonic quality per se

author: Juliette
content:
Between the clip gain, the track volume, and the amount of compression being applied on the mixbus, what’s the first thing you should be looking at if something if something is a little too loud or a little too quiet in a mix?

My first thought is always “Okay, I’ll turn the track volume up more.” But then I wonder if that will cause it to become more drowned out due to the compressor on the master. I’m sure there’s many ways to go about it. But what’s the most efficient way without sending yourself down a rabbit hole of volume-wars?

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
Fleshed out a bit more- I think it depends where the 17 revisions are coming from. 

- Are they easily actionable things? I'd probably just do it.
- Are we spinning our wheels with indecision from a new artist? I'd still probably do it, but there's a point where I'd try to back channel with the producer, or if there is no producer, have a sit-down with the artist
- Is it a major label thing where there are 10 people involved in approvals? Buy the ticket, take the ride, get that sweet major label $$$.

author: Chase H
content:
I’m in the middle mixing an album for a band that records their vocals on an Aston Spirit mic that I always struggle with esses on when mixing and I’m struggling to get their Esses to where they are happy with them.

It’s a male and female both singing so my gut instinct was to choose just one S to be present most of the time.
On the 2nd revision and left the Esses completely alone after hearing they hated how they sounded the first pass (manually de essed with volume automation) and they dislike the Esses being untouched much more.

Next approach I’m going to try tomorrow is get them to choose an S they like and manually use that to replace the others with.

If that doesn’t work does anyone have another suggestion I should try?

author: Iwan Morgan
content: Could always automate the de-esser for specific parts and/or use the clip fx EQ on a high shelf if the top is too bright on specific esses. Massey De-Esser in split band or Lindell 902 are my most musical sounding favourites for this.

author: kalpipal
content: If you're talking heavy mix bus compression: if you can use an external side chain on your bus comp (and it isn't already being used), I'd create a sidechain bus and send every single relevant track/bus to it **pre-fader** at the track's approximate level (trying to get pre-fader send level to match post-fader so the sum total drives the comp the same way as it would in the mix.)

author: Juliette

author: James Cronier
content:
If you’re on pro tools, an avid artist mix is $200-300 and will let you do plenty of EQ-ing and other processing with the screen off. *IF*  you take some time to learn what plugs map to it well. 

Even just pushing the faders and pans with no display is amazing. 

I don’t do it all the time, but sometimes if I’m stuck on a song, I will turn the TV off and use the memory locations, FF/REW and spacebar for transport. Faders, sends, pan, mutes, solos, and EQ all happen on the artist mix. I go this route every third mix or so these days, a majority of the time I don’t and I just write some automation on the artist mix.

author: James Cronier
content: I love thriving in this space. Nothing better than making a great mix from a producer feel perfect for the team. A part of my growth as a mixer has been accepting that my contribution can be objectively very small but still valuable nonetheless. An above average producer’s time is better spent working on another song. I can take a lot off their plate spending an extra hour on EQ, another hour going deep on vocal automation/edit cleanup. That can feel priceless to a busy producer/artist team.

author: Will Trotman
content: Do you guys strictly clip gain down esses or do we get weird with a little volume (fader) automation here? I keep finding that after a vocal is compressed, just doing some volume automation gets the job done better for me. But I feel like I only hear people talk about clip gaining esses and curious if there's a reason for that.
